Section Title: ASSUREDPARTNERS, INC. NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: ASSUREDPARTNERS, INC. NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (UNAUDITED) 1. Overview and Basis of Presentation
Subsubsection Text: As a result of the impact of push-down accounting, the accompanying consolidated financial statements and the notes thereto are presented with two distinct periods, the period before the consummation of the Merger from January 1, 2019 through May 12, 2019 (labeled Predecessor or referred to as the Predecessor Period) and the period after the Merger from May 13, 2019 and thereafter (labeled Successor or referred to as the Successor Period) to indicate the application of a different basis of accounting between the periods presented. The historical financial and other data prior to the closing of the Merger have been prepared using the historical results of operations and basis of the assets and liabilities of the Predecessor. In addition, the Company adopted ASU 201409, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606) and related interpretations (ASC 606), using a modified retrospective approach for the Successor Period ending December 31, 2019 and all subsequent interim periods. As such, the accompanying consolidated financial statements for the Successor Period ending September 30, 2019 have been prepared in accordance with ASC 605, Revenue Recognition. The accompanying unaudited interim consolidated financial statements include the accounts of AssuredPartners, Inc., and all of its wholly-owned subsidiaries. These statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (US GAAP). Accordingly, certain information and footnote disclosures normally included in the Company’s annual F-58 -----

Section Title: ASSUREDPARTNERS, INC. NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: the reporting period. The principal estimates used include, among others, the allocation of purchase price to the fair value of net assets acquired in connection with acquisitions, the valuation of earn-out payables established as of the date of acquisitions, the adoption of and accounting under the new revenue recognition standard, equitybased compensation, reserves for unpaid losses and loss adjustment expenses, and the estimated fair value of financial instruments. Actual results may differ from those estimates. equivalents should be included with cash and cash equivalents when reconciling the beginning-of-period and end-of-period total amounts shown on the statement of cash flows. The ASU 2016-18 is required to be adopted using the full retrospective approach and is effective for annual periods presented beginning after December 15, 2018 and interim reporting periods within annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2019 for nonpublic companies. Prior to the adoption of ASU 2016-18, the change in restricted cash and trust cash balances were reported as operating activities on the statements of cash flows. The net cash provided by operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2018 were previously reported as $113.5 million. With the adoption of ASU 2016-18, the net cash provided by operating activities for the aforementioned period is reported as $105.8 million. In August 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-15, Statements of Cash Flows: Classification of Certain Cash _Receipts and Cash Payments (ASU 2016-15), which provides additional guidance on eight specific cash flow_ issues and reduces diversity in practices of how certain cash receipts and cash payments are presented and classified in the statements of cash flows. For nonpublic companies, ASU 2016-15 is effective fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, and interim periods within fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019. Adoption of ASU 2016-15 did not have any material impact on the Company’s consolidated financial statements. In January 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-01, Financial Instruments—Overall (Subtopic 825-10) _Recognition and Measurement of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities (ASU 2016-01). ASU 2016-01_ eliminates the requirement to disclose the fair value of financial instruments measured at amortized cost for nonpublic business entities. These amendments are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, including interim periods within the fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019. The Company no longer discloses fair value of financial instruments that are measured at amortized cost within the notes to the consolidated financial statements. In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606) (ASU 2014-09). The amendments in ASU 2014-09 outline a single comprehensive model that replaces most existing US GAAP revenue recognition guidance and depicts the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services. Adoption of ASU 2014-09 for nonpublic companies is required for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2018 and interim reporting periods within annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2019. As a result of the Merger, the Company’s date of adoption in the Successor Period begins on the date of the closing of the Merger, May 13, 2019. The Company adopted ASU 2014-09 using a modified retrospective approach which required the Company to record cumulative effect of adjustment to retained earnings on the adoption date. See Note 3, Revenues from Contracts with Customers. circumstances, the Company provides more than one performance obligation to the customer that is comprised of placement of an insurance policy and other services. The Company allocates the commissions and fees revenues with respect to each performance obligation by recognizing 80% of the revenues, which relate to the placement of insurance policy, on the effective date of the respective insurance policy; and recognizing the remaining 20% over the term of the insurance policy, which is generally one year or less, as the services are rendered. _Contingent Revenue. Supplemental and profit-sharing contingent commissions from insurance companies_ are recognized in the same point in time as the commission revenue. A supplemental commission is a commission paid by an insurance carrier that is above the base commission paid, is based on historical performance criteria and is established annually in advance of the contractual period. A profit-sharing contingent commission is a commission paid by an insurance carrier and is based on, among other things, the overall underwriting results and/or growth of the business placed with that insurance carrier during a particular calendar year and is determined after the contractual period. These revenues are variable in nature and not determinable until all contingencies are resolved. As such, these contingent revenues are estimated and accrued on the effective date of an insurance policy, with an amount of consideration that will be received from the insurance carrier in the following year. _Costs. Costs incurred by the Company to obtain a customer contract (Costs to Obtain) are capitalized and_ amortized over 15 years based on the expected life of the underlying customer relationships. Certain contract related costs, including pre-placement brokerage costs to fulfill a customer contract (Costs to Fulfill), are capitalized and are amortized on a systematic basis consistent with the transfer of control of the services to which the asset relates, which is generally less than one year. the insurance companies remit to the Company its earned commissions. Accordingly, commissions receivables are accounts receivable from insurance companies. two-step quantitative impairment test, the Company uses a discounted cash flow valuation method (the income approach). The Company completed its annual goodwill impairment assessment; and no impairment was recognized as of September 30, 2019. There were no events or changes since the period following the annual impairment review through December 31, 2019 that caused the Company to perform an interim period impairment assessment. Amortizable intangible assets are stated at cost, less accumulated amortization. Purchased customer accounts and noncompete agreements are amortized on a straight-line basis over the related estimated lives and contract periods, which range from five to twenty years. Purchased customer accounts primarily consist of records and files that contain information about insurance policies and the related insured parties that are essential to policy renewals. Purchased trade name is amortized over five years. The favorable lease assets or unfavorable lease liabilities that arise from the business combinations are amortized over the remaining term of the respective lease agreements. possible adjustments based on data such as historical and projected claim incidence patterns, claim size, expected payment patterns and period. The Company recognizes the best estimate of the ultimate liability under moderately adverse conditions. The methods for making such estimates and for establishing the resulting liability are continually reviewed and any adjustments are reflected in current earnings. effect on the last day of the year. Income and expense accounts were translated at the average exchange rate in effect during the year. Translation adjustments arising from the use of differing exchange rates from period to period are included in the accumulated other comprehensive loss within the consolidated statements of equity. The $2.3 billion of intangible assets acquired in connection with the Merger were assigned to the following: The Company previously recorded revenue at the later of the billing or the effective date of the insurance policy. Under ASC 606, revenues from commissions and fees are recorded when the control transfers to the customer upon fulfillment of the performance obligation; and the remuneration is reasonably determinable. The resulting impact is a shift in timing from revenue recognition patterns that were historically correlated to customer billings. Certain costs that were historically expensed as incurred under the previous revenue standard are capitalized or deferred under ASC 606. These costs are directly attributable to generating revenues that include costs for obtaining and fulfilling a contract. These costs are now recognized as assets that are amortized on a systematic basis that is consistent with the transfer of the services to which the assets relate. The impact of adoption of ASC 606 on the Company’s consolidated statements of operations for the Successor period ended December 31, 2019 was as follows: _Services & Other: The Company offers various services which include, but are not limited to, risk_ management, consulting and third-party administration services to customers in a wide variety of industries. The carrying amount of the amortizable intangible assets, net are as follows: require interest to be paid semi-annually at an annual rate of 8.00% on May 15 and November 15, starting November 15, 2019. The 2027 Notes mature on May 15, 2027 unless redeemed earlier or repurchased. The Company incurred arrangement and professional fees of approximately $20.5 million which have been directly deducted from the carrying value. The 2027 Notes are fully and unconditionally guaranteed on a joint-and-several basis by the Company’s 100% owned domestic subsidiaries. The 2027 Notes are senior unsecured obligations of the Company and are senior in right of payment to all existing and future subordinated indebtedness of the Company, including subordinated promissory notes, such as notes payable issued in connection with acquisitions; and rank equally in right of payment with all existing and future senior indebtedness of the Company, including the existing Credit Facility obligations and the 2025 Notes. The 2027 Notes are effectively subordinated to the obligations under the existing Credit Facility, to the extent of the value of the assets securing such indebtedness. The Company is not required to make any mandatory redemption or sinking fund payments with respect to the 2027 Notes. The Company may redeem the 2027 Notes, in whole or in part, at any time prior to May 15, 2022, at a redemption price calculated using a formula designed to provide the bondholders with a “make-whole” premium. Before May 15, 2022, the Company may also redeem, on one or more occasions, at a price equal to 108% plus accrued interest, up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the 2027 Notes in an amount not to exceed the net cash proceeds of certain equity offerings; provided that at least 50% of the 2027 Notes originally issued on May 13, 2019 remain outstanding after giving effect to such redemption. Beginning on May 15, 2022, the Company may redeem the 2027 Notes at redemption prices beginning at 104%, reducing to 102% on May 15, 2023 and reducing to 100% on May 15, 2024. The 2027 Notes are not subject to any maintenance or financial covenants. However, there are affirmative covenants (e.g., the Company is required to maintain and deliver certain financial information every quarter) and negative covenants (e.g., the Company is limited from incurring additional indebtedness, making payments to the Company’s shareholders and selling certain of its assets, except, in each case, as otherwise permitted) with which the Company must comply. If the Company experiences a Change of Control (other than a Permitted Change of Control), the Company is required to offer to repurchase the 2027 Notes at 101% of the principal amount of such 2027 Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the date of repurchase. However, the 2027 Notes also include a change of control portability feature whereby the Company does not have to make an offer to repurchase the 2027 Notes (and holders of the 2027 Notes do not have the ability to require such repurchase), so long as the change of control qualifies as a Permitted Change of Control. In order to qualify as a Permitted Change of Control, on the date of the change of control: a. The Company’s Moody’s corporate rating must be B3 (stable) or better, and the Company’s S&P corporate rating must be B (stable) or better; and b. The Consolidated Total Net Debt Ratio is equal to or less than 7.00x. for the First Lien Term Loans. Effective May 13, 2019, the Company’s Credit Facility no longer includes a Permitted Change of Control provision. On May 13, 2019, the Company entered into the Seventh Incremental Assumption and Amendment Agreement (Amendment No. 7), which amends the Credit Facility to terminate the Revolver Loans and entered into a new revolving credit facility (New Revolver Loans). The New Revolver Loans have borrowing limits up to $267.5 million and are scheduled to mature on April 22, 2024. Borrowings under the New Revolver Loans accrue interest at LIBOR, plus the applicable margin of 3.50%. All obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility are unconditionally guaranteed by the Company. All obligations under the New Revolver Loans, and the guarantees of such obligations, are secured by substantially all assets of the Successor Company and each guarantor, subject to certain exceptions. The First Lien Term Loans continue to be not subject to any maintenance financial covenants. However, the New Revolver Loans are subject to a springing leverage covenant in the event the aggregate principal amount of outstanding Revolver Loans and letters of credit exceed, were amended from 30% to 35% of the revolving commitments at the end of each fiscal quarter. Upon becoming subject to the springing covenant, the required ratio of first lien indebtedness (first lien debt outstanding less operating cash) to EBITDA was amended from not being greater than 6.25:1 beginning December 31, 2018 and thereafter to not being greater than 7.50:1 beginning June 30, 2019 and thereafter. The Credit Facility also contains affirmative covenants (e.g., the Company is required to make certain prepayments out of cash flow) and negative covenants (e.g., the Company is limited from incurring additional indebtedness, making payments to the Company’s equity unit holders and selling certain of its assets, except, in each case, as otherwise permitted) that remained the same. In addition, the Company also entered into the Eighth Incremental Assumption and Amendment Agreement (Amendment No. 8), which amends the Credit Facility to obtain a delayed draw term loan facility (Delayed Draw Term Loan) with a borrowing limit of up to $250.0 million. The Delayed Draw Term Loan constitutes a separate class from the Company’s existing term loan facility and is not fungible with the Company’s existing term loan facility. The Company intends to use proceeds from any future borrowings to fund future acquisitions and for other general corporate purposes. The commitments of lenders to fund under the Delayed Draw Term Loan is subject to certain conditions, including compliance with certain leverage ratios, the accuracy of certain representations and other customary conditions. The Delayed Draw Term Loan was issued at a discount of 100 basis points, totaling $2.5 million and is scheduled to mature on October 22, 2024. Borrowings under the Delayed Draw Term Loan bear interest at a rate per annum equal to an applicable margin plus, Base rate or LIBOR rate available at the time of borrowing. The Delayed Draw Term Loan may be drawn up to six times at any time on or prior to the date that is two years after the closing date, May 13, 2019. Each borrowing is subject to quarterly amortization payments, whereby 0.25% of the original principal amount of the Delayed Draw Term Loan are repaid on the first full quarter following the date of funding. Similar to the First Lien Term Loans, the remaining aggregate principal of all Delayed Draw Term Loans will be payable in full on the maturity date. Repayments and prepayments may not be reborrowed. On August 30, 2019, the Company drew down $85.0 million from the Delayed Draw Term Loan. The first quarterly amortization payment began on December 31, 2019. For the New Revolver Loans and Delayed Draw Term Loan, the Company incurred arrangement, up-front and professional fees of approximately $7.9 million and $5.9 million, respectively. On November 25, 2019, the Company entered into the Ninth Incremental Assumption and Amendment Agreement, which amends the Credit Facility for the First Lien Term Loans. The Company borrowed an F-34 ----- additional $170.0 million in First Lien Term Loans through a privately placed transaction. The incremental borrowings were used to repay borrowings under the New Revolver Loans and pay fees and expenses incurred in connection with the refinancing, which approximated $3.7 million. The incremental portion was issued at the discount of 96 basis points, which totaled $1.6 million. No other key terms were amended. Future annual principal payments due on the Company’s indebtedness are as follows: fourth anniversary of the effective date of the Third Incremental Assumption and Amendment Agreement, dated on September 27, 2017, if the following provisions are met: a. The issuer’s Moody’s corporate rating is B3 (stable) or better, and the Company’s S&P corporate rating is B (stable) or better; b. The Consolidated Total Net Debt Ratio is equal to or less than 6.85 times; c. The issuer provides a notice of the Permitted Change of Control at least 15 business days prior and customary information no later than 3 days prior to the effectiveness of Permitted Change of Control; and d. Only one Permitted Change of Control event is allowed. Amounts outstanding under the Credit Facility accrue interest at rates that are variable. The Company’s borrowings under the Credit Facility were designated as LIBOR-based loans which accrue interest at an applicable margin above a certain threshold. The threshold for LIBOR-based borrowings was the 30-day market LIBOR rate. The applicable margin for the First Lien Term Loans is 3.25% and when a Permitted Change of Control occurs, the applicable margin increases to 3.50%. Upon the consummation of the Merger, the applicable margin for the First Lien Term Loans increased to 3.50%. In addition, the Company repaid all amounts outstanding under the Revolver Loans and terminated the Revolver Loans as the Revolver Loans were not included under the Permitted Change of Control provision. Unamortized portion of deferred debt issuance costs of $2.2 million related to the Revolver Loans were written-off and recorded in the debt extinguishment loss within the Predecessor consolidated statements of operations. exceed the net cash proceeds of certain equity offerings; provided that at least 50% of the 2025 Notes originally issued on August 2, 2017 remain outstanding after giving effect to such redemption. Beginning on August 15, 2020, the Company may redeem the 2025 Notes at redemption prices beginning at 103.50%, reducing to 101.75% on August 15, 2021 and reducing to 100.00% on August 15, 2022. The 2025 Notes are not subject to any maintenance or financial covenants. However, there are affirmative covenants (e.g., the Company is required to maintain and deliver certain financial information every quarter) and negative covenants (e.g., the Company is limited from incurring additional indebtedness, making payments to the Company’s shareholders and selling certain of its assets, except, in each case, as otherwise permitted) with which the Company must comply. The 2025 Notes also include a portability feature that is similar to the provision included in the First Lien Term Loans discussed above, whereby portability is allowed if the Permitted Change of Control occurs before the maturity of the 2025 Notes. However, portability feature in the 2025 Notes are not restricted to one-time use, unlike the First Lien Term Loans. Pursuant to the Plan, and as approved by the Board of Directors (the Board) of the Parent, the Parent grants, and/or provides an opportunity to purchase, its equity units to certain participating employees of the Company, who have substantial responsibility for the management and growth of the organization. At December 31, 2019, the Company had a federal net operating loss carry forward of $114.2 million and $10.4 million of state NOLs of varying amounts, which will begin to expire in 2031. For the Successor period ended December 31, 2019, Predecessor period ended May 12, 2019 and Predecessor year ended 2018, the Company recorded net deferred tax assets which include a valuation allowance of $7.2 million, $7.2 million and $7.2 million, respectively, related to state NOLs. The state NOLs may be carried forward to offset future taxable income. Realization is dependent upon generating sufficient taxable income prior to the expiration of the NOLs. For the Successor period ended December 31, 2019, Predecessor period ended May 12, 2019 and Predecessor year ended 2018, the Company had income attributable to foreign subsidiaries of less than $0.1 million, $0.1 million and $1.9 million, respectively. The Tax Act subjects a U.S. shareholder to current tax on global intangible low-taxed income (“GILTI”) earned by certain foreign subsidiaries. The Company elected to utilize current NOL carryforwards to offset the GILTI taxable inclusion and therefore did not record any related income tax payable for U.S. federal tax purposes. Also, the Company should not recognize any additional U.S. tax on the repatriation of foreign earnings considered to be previously taxed earnings from the toll charge inclusion accounted for in the 2017 tax year. The Company has conducted business and files tax returns in the U.S. and U.K. The Company’s U.S. federal and various state returns are subject to examination for the years 2012 and later, due to NOLs generated in 2012. The Company’s U.K. returns for the year 2018 and later are subject to examination. and Predecessor Period ended December 31, 2018, under these leases were $4.0 million, $2.2 million and $5.9 million respectively. There are a variety of legal proceedings pending or threatened against the Company. Accruals are recorded when it is probable a liability has been incurred and the amount of the liability can be reasonably estimated based on current law, progress of each case, opinions and views of legal counsel and other advisers, and the Company’s experience in similar matters and intended response to the litigation. These amounts, which are not discounted and are exclusive of claims against third parties, are adjusted periodically as assessment efforts progress or additional information becomes available. The Company expenses amounts for administering or litigating claims as incurred. Neither the outcomes of these matters nor their effect upon the Company’s business, financial condition or results of operations can be determined at this time. all three of the draw-downs begin on June 30, 2020. The Company drew down the $250.0 million of the borrowing capacity upon the draw on March 20, 2020 and there are no more draw-downs available from the Delayed Draw Term Loan. On February 13, 2020, the Company entered into the Tenth Incremental Assumption and Amendment Agreement (the Tenth Amendment), which amends the Credit Facility for the First Lien Term Loans and the New Revolver. Through the Tenth Amendment, the Company borrowed an additional $250.0 million in the First Lien Term Loans; increased the borrowing limit on the New Revolver from $267.5 million to $414.5 million; and extended the maturity of the First Lien Term Loans by seven years and the New Revolver by five years from the effective date of the Tenth Amendment. In addition, the Company refinanced First Lien Term Loans including the incremental portion and were issued at a discount of 25 basis points, which approximated $5.3 million. The incremental borrowings were used to repay existing borrowings under the New Revolver Loans and pay fees and expenses incurred in connection with the refinancing through the Tenth Amendment. The First Lien Term Loans contain a six-month soft call provision which requires the Company to pay a call premium of 1% of the outstanding First Lien Term Loan balance in the event of a refinancing event. The six-month call provision was reset on February 13, 2020. On March 30, 2020, the Company entered into the Eleventh Amendment Agreement, (the Eleventh Amendment) which amends the Credit Facility with respect to the delivery of financial statements be within 90 days after the end of each fiscal year to within 120 days specifically for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2019. As a result of the Eleventh Amendment, the Company paid approximately $3.7 million of fees and related expenses.

Section Title: ASSUREDPARTNERS, INC. NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (UNAUDITED)
Subsubsection Text: On May 13, 2019, the Company issued, at par, $475.0 million of 8.00% senior notes due 2027 (the 2027 Notes). The 2027 Notes were issued in a private transaction that is not subject to the registration requirements of the Securities Act of 1933, or the ongoing reporting requirements of the Securities Act of 1934. The 2027 Notes require interest to be paid semi-annually at an annual rate of 8.00% on May 15 and November 15, starting November 15, 2019. The 2027 Notes mature on May 15, 2027 unless redeemed earlier or repurchased. The Company incurred arrangement and professional fees of approximately $20.5 million which have been directly deducted from the carrying value. The 2027 Notes are fully and unconditionally guaranteed on a joint-and-several basis by the Company’s 100% owned domestic subsidiaries. The 2027 Notes are senior unsecured obligations of the Company and are senior in right of payment to all existing and future subordinated indebtedness of the Company, including subordinated promissory notes, such as notes payable issued in connection with acquisitions; and rank equally in right of payment with all existing and future senior indebtedness of the Company, including the existing Credit Facility obligations and the 2025 Notes. The 2027 Notes are effectively subordinated to the obligations under the existing Credit Facility, to the extent of the value of the assets securing such indebtedness. The Company is not required to make any mandatory redemption or sinking fund payments with respect to the 2027 Notes. The Company may redeem the 2027 Notes, in whole or in part, at any time prior to May 15, 2022, at a redemption price calculated using a formula designed to provide the bondholders with a “make-whole” premium. Before May 15, 2022, the Company may also redeem, on one or more occasions, at a price equal to 108% plus accrued interest, up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the 2027 Notes in an amount not to exceed the net cash proceeds of certain equity offerings; provided that at least 50% of the 2027 Notes originally issued on May 13, 2019 remain outstanding after giving effect to such redemption. Beginning on May 15, 2022, the Company may redeem the 2027 Notes at redemption prices beginning at 104%, reducing to 102% on May 15, 2023 and reducing to 100% on May 15, 2024. F-67 -----

Subsection Title: 7. Fair Value of Measurements and Financial Instruments
Subsubsection Text: Interest rate swaps are valued using pricing models that are based on certain assumptions and readily observable market-based inputs, including yield curves and implied volatilities of closely related instruments, for which transparent pricing is available. The Company reflects the credit considerations inherent in the derivative contracts with both positive and negative exposures over the remaining life of the derivative. The credit spreads calculated for each party (e.g., the hedging entity and the bank counterparty) are converted into default probabilities. The default probabilities of the hedging entity are applied to the negative exposures, resulting in a positive credit adjustment (the DVA), and the default probabilities of the bank counterparty are applied to the positive exposures, resulting in a negative credit adjustment (the CVA). The bilateral credit valuation adjustment is the sum of the positive and negative adjustments. F-70 -----

Subsection Title: 7. Fair Value of Measurements and Financial Instruments
Subsubsection Text: Accounting standards establish a three-tier fair value hierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs used in measuring fair values as follows: Level 1 Observable inputs such as quoted prices for identical assets in active markets; Level 2 Inputs other than quoted prices for identical assets in active markets, that are observable either directly or indirectly; and Level 3 Unobservable inputs in which there is little or no market data which requires the use of valuation techniques and the development of assumptions. Subsubsection Text: The effective tax rate for the nine months ended September 30, 2020, period from May 13, 2019 through September 30, 2019 (Successor) and period from January 1, 2019 through May 12, 2019 (Predecessor) was 31.7%, 22.2%, and 0.6%, respectively. The change in the effective tax rate is primarily due to impacts of state taxes and permanent tax differences. A valuation allowance has been established against the deferred tax assets related to certain state net operating losses (NOLs) for which it is not more likely than not that the benefit will be realized. The Company evaluates the recoverability of the deferred tax assets on a regular basis based upon all available positive and negative evidence. F-73 -----

Subsection Title: ASSUREDPARTNERS, INC. NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (UNAUDITED) 10. Commitments and Contingencies
Subsubsection Text: There are a variety of legal proceedings pending or threatened against the Company. Accruals are recorded when it is probable a liability has been incurred and the amount of the liability can be reasonably estimated based on current law, progress of each case, opinions and views of legal counsel and other advisers, and the Company’s experience in similar matters and intended response to the litigation. These amounts, which are not discounted and are exclusive of claims against third parties, are adjusted periodically as assessment efforts progress or additional information becomes available. The Company expenses amounts for administering or litigating claims as incurred. Neither the outcomes of these matters nor their effect upon the Company’s business, financial condition or results of operations can be determined at this time.

Subsubsection Text: consolidated financial statements have been condensed or omitted. The accompanying unaudited interim consolidated financial statements should be read in conjunction with the audited annual consolidated financial statements and related notes for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2019. Total consideration transferred during the nine months ended September 30, 2020 are as follows: A reconciliation of the acquisition earn-out payables is as follows: The number, fair values, and duration of investments in a continuous loss position are as follows: Expected maturities may differ from stated due dates because borrowers may have the right to call or prepay obligations. The 2027 Notes are not subject to any maintenance or financial covenants. However, there are affirmative covenants (e.g., the Company is required to maintain and deliver certain financial information every quarter) and negative covenants (e.g., the Company is limited from incurring additional indebtedness, making payments to the Company’s shareholders and selling certain of its assets, except, in each case, as otherwise permitted) with which the Company must comply. If the Company experiences a Change of Control (other than a Permitted Change of Control), the Company is required to offer to repurchase the 2027 Notes at 101% of the principal amount of such 2027 Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the date of repurchase. However, the 2027 Notes also include a change of control portability feature whereby the Company does not have to make an offer to repurchase the 2027 Notes (and holders of the 2027 Notes do not have the ability to require such repurchase), so long as the change of control qualifies as a Permitted Change of Control. In order to qualify as a Permitted Change of Control, on the date of the change of control: a. The Company’s Moody’s corporate rating must be B3 (stable) or better, and the Company’s S&P corporate rating must be B (stable) or better; and b. The Consolidated Total Net Debt Ratio is equal to or less than 7.00x. In addition, the Company also entered into the Eighth Incremental Assumption and Amendment Agreement (Amendment No. 8), which amends the Credit Facility to obtain a delayed draw term loan facility (Delayed Draw Term Loan) with a borrowing limit of up to $250.0 million. The Delayed Draw Term Loan constitutes a separate class from the Company’s existing term loan facility and is not fungible with the Company’s existing term loan facility. The Company intends to use proceeds from any future borrowings to fund future acquisitions and for other general corporate purposes. The commitments of lenders to fund under the Delayed Draw Term Loan is subject to certain conditions, including compliance with certain leverage ratios, the accuracy of certain representations and other customary conditions. The Delayed Draw Term Loan was issued at a discount of 100 basis points, totaling $2.5 million and is scheduled to mature on October 22, 2024. Borrowings under the Delayed Draw Term Loan bear interest at a rate per annum equal to an applicable margin plus, Base rate or LIBOR rate available at the time of borrowing. The Delayed Draw Term Loan may be drawn up to nine times at any time on or prior to the date that is two years after the closing date, May 13, 2019. Each borrowing is subject to quarterly amortization payments, whereby 0.25% of the original principal amount of the Delayed Draw Term Loan are repaid on the first full quarter following the date of funding. Similar to the First Lien Term Loans, the remaining aggregate principal of all Delayed Draw Term Loans will be payable in full on the maturity date. Repayments and prepayments may not be reborrowed. On June 2, 2020, the Company entered into the Twelfth Incremental Assumption and Amendment Agreement (the Twelfth Amendment), which amends the credit facility for the First Lien Term Loans and the New Revolver. Through the Twelfth Amendment, the Company borrowed an additional $300.0 million in First Lien Term Loans, which were issued at a discount of 200 basis points which approximated $6.0 million. The incremental borrowings were used to repay existing borrowings under the New Revolver Loans and pay fees and expenses incurred in connection with the refinancing of approximately $5.1 million. The Company accounted for the incremental borrowings from the Twelfth Amendment as a new debt and capitalized related the debt issuance costs. Certain key terms for the incremental borrowings were different from the terms on the existing first lien term loans. The applicable margin, which is 3.5% for the existing first lien term loans, was priced at 4.5% subject to a 1% LIBOR floor. In addition, the Twelfth Amendment contains a twelve-month call provision for the incremental borrowings (as opposed to a nine-month soft call for the existing first lien term loans). In the event the Company encounters a prepayment event prior to the twelve-month anniversary of the effective date of the Twelfth Amendment, the Company is required to pay the greater of a call premium of 1% of the outstanding incremental first lien borrowings through the Twelfth Amendment or the make-whole premium amount, which is defined by the Twelfth Amendment. The incremental borrowings from the Twelfth Amendment is subject to 0.25% of quarterly principal amortization payments beginning June 30, 2020 and matures on February 13, 2027. The Twelfth Amendment did not contain any changes to the First Lien Term Loans that existed prior to the Twelfth Amendment. However, the nature of all the businesses acquired is similar in all material respects to the acquisitions previously completed by the Company, and as such the Company expects the purchase price to be allocated in a similar manner.
